DOC.HEAD: U.S. Helicopters Gave Warning, Then Sent Residents Scurrying
With AM-Panama Bjt
Eds: ``plenty people'' cq in 10th graf
DOC.TEXT: Rolando Diaz learned of the battle to oust Manuel Noriega when he heard the buzz of U.S. helicopters over his neighborhood, which then broadcast warnings to soldiers at a nearby military headquarters to leave the building. ``They were shouting down over the PA system. ... They said they had no problem with them, they just wanted Noriega,'' he said in a telephone interview from Panama, through an interpreter. Then the shooting began in Panama City. Fires triggered by the battle leveled turn-of-the century wooden homes in a three-block area. Diaz, who escaped with 11 members of his extended family, said he counted six bodies of those loyal to Noriega lying dead in the streets as he and others fled the immediate area. Many ended up at the nearby Salvation Army office. ``They were carrying TVs and their belongings on their heads,'' Marjorie Wiltshire, whose husband heads the office, said in a telephone interview. The Salvation Army offered refugees from the fighting cookies and punch _ the only food available _ then began cooking lentils and rice for a midday meal. ``That's all we have. We can't get out to get to a store,'' Mrs. Wiltshire said. Diaz and his family were escorted by U.S. soldiers to a church, where they took shelter for about five hours until the church was hit by an incendiary device. ``The church also burned down,'' said Diaz, 32. Diaz, a clerk in the ministry of education, sought shelter along with about 100 other people at the Salvation Army office near the entrance to the Panama Canal. He escaped with a few extra pants and shirts. Everything else was destroyed. ``They burned everything down,'' Manuel Backalt, another civilian who fled from the area of Noriega's headquarters with his wife and three children, said in English. ``I see plenty people dead in the street.'' The fires in the houses resulted from the intense fighting; they were not targets, eyewitnesses said. Backalt said the bodies _ he did not know how many _ were mainly members of the Dignity Battalion, a paramilitary group loyal to Noriega. Backalt, a self-employed stove repairman, said he was sleeping when he heard gunfire. He said his house caught fire, and he and his family went out into the street. None of his family was injured. As they walked the streets, he said, they saw a helicopter crash. He said he didn't know if it was American or a Panamanian helicopter. Although he lost his home, Diaz said he was glad the U.S. decided to attack. ``This is the best thing that could have happened,'' he said. Because Noriega's headquarters was located in a slum section of the city, most of those left homeless are poor, said Maj. Allan Wiltshire, who runs the Salvation Army office.
